awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nanodiamond Particle Fabrication by Confined Laser Shock Detonation for Drug Delivery and Other Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanodiamonds, or nanosized diamond particles, have been widely explored as drug delivery vehicles and bio-imaging agents for biomedical treatments ranging from oncology to infection to regenerative medicine.  However, the manufacture of medical quality nanodiamonds is difficult, costly, and energy intensive.  The existing methods for nanodiamond fabrication often rely on a chemical detonation process, which suffers from poor controllability, complex experimental set-ups, and safety issues.  This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge required for the development of a simple and cost-effective nanomanufacturing process to fabricate nanodiamonds under ambient conditions.  Using this easy and viable route for nanodiamond fabrication, many complex nanodiamond-based devices for biomedical, electronics, and optics applications can be built at low cost.  Such a capability impacts key U.S. industries thus enhancing national prosperity and security.  The research results will be integrated into a comic book -- Nanodiamond Nora and Neal -- targeted to engage K-12 students.  In addition, this project provides an integrated training platform for undergraduate and graduate students, and promotes broadening participation of women and underrepresented students in research.

This project aims to establish a new nanomanufacturing strategy for nanodiamond fabrication.  It is hypothesized that the laser-induced plasma in the nanosecond pulsed laser shock processing, can provide sufficient energy input and duration to promote the graphite-to-diamond phase transition.  To test this hypothesis, a confined laser shock detonation approach is planned to realize the scalable nanomanufacturing of nanodiamonds at room-temperature and in open air, through utilizing high-energy laser-matter interaction phenomena.  The major research objective is to establish a fundamental understanding of mechanisms involved in the confined laser shock detonation process that are responsible for the growth of nanodiamonds.  First-principles modeling and molecular dynamics simulations performed at ASU and UNR, help understand the laser-graphite interactions and the plasma dynamics that lead to the graphite-to-diamond phase transition.  Biocompatibility of laser-fabricated nanodiamonds is evaluated through collaboration between ASU and UCLA to demonstrate potential applications in drug delivery and bio-imaging.  This project contributes to advances in laser-based nanomanufacturing and innovations in nanomaterials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project established a novel confined laser shock detonation (CLSD) process to realize scalable, room-temperature nanomanufacturing of nanodiamonds (NDs) in open air towards multi-model drug delivery applications. A comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms involved in the CLSD process that could lead to fast, controlled manufacturing of NDs from graphite raw materials is gained. Specifically, this project studied the mechanism of laser matter interaction and carbon plasma hydrodynamics, which lead to high pressure shockwave under confinement to stimulate graphite-to-diamond phase transition, developed the CLSD process setup for NDs fabrication, and  revealed the microstructure and biocompatibility of CLSD-fabricated NDs for future bio-related applications.

The major outcomes include: 1) first principles based models demonstrated that a high pressure shockwave can be generated when the laser induced plasma expansion is well confined, while the shockwave pressure and duration are closely related to the laser parameters (Image 1); 2) molecule dynamics simulation models demonstrated that the laser induced carbon plasma mainly leads to formation of amorphous carbon when they are condensed (Image 2 left), however the shockwave pressure resulted from carbon plasma expansion can well compress the meta-stable graphite and then realize the graphite-to-diamond phase transition during the CLSD process (Image 2 right); 3) molecular dynamics simulation process study demonstrated that both shockwave pressure duration and pressure magnitude have significant effects on diamond formation in the CLSD process (Image 3); 4) an ensemble learning potential demonstrated high accuracy comparing to conventional atomic potentials when it is utilized in large scale classical molecular dynamics simulations of carbon structures (Image 4); 5) A pressure-temperature window is identified in the CLSD process that ND formation will mainly happened with validation from characterizations from x-ray diffraction patterns and microscopic observations (Image 5); 6) manufactured NDs are filled into polymer matrix for 3D printing of bioimplant devices, which demonstrated ultrahigh biocompatibility promoting both cells seeding and growth (Image 6).


Last Modified: 12/04/2023
Modified by: Qiong Nian

Images (1 of )
  • Thermo-hydrodynamic simulations of CLSD with a rigid confinement (400 J cm−2 laser fluence, 10 ns pulse duration, and 5 ns delay time): temporal and spatial evolutions of (a) temperature, (b) electron number density, (c) pressure, and (d) particle velocity.
    Qiong Nian, Yiliang Liao
    Copyrighted
    Qiong Nian
    Image 1
  • (a) Ensemble learning framework . (b) SA histogram plot comparing the mean average error (MAE) in the formation energy from empirical potentials (light blue bars) to that from ensemble learning models (orange bars). (c) Predicted elastic constants under Tersoff and ensemble learning.
    Qiong Nian, Houlong Zhuang
    Copyrighted
    Qiong Nian
    Image 4
  • MD simulation of CLSD process study: left, CLSD pressure duration effect on graphite-to-diamond phase transition when a 2Km/s shockwave is applied; right, CLSD pressure magnitude effect on graphite-to-diamond phase transition when shockwaves with various speeds are applied.
    Qiong Nian
    Copyrighted
    Qiong Nian
    Image 3
  • A pressure-temperature window identified for ND formation (top left); X-ray diffraction of formed NDs (top right); scanning electron microscopy observation of NDs (bottom left); transmission electron microscopy observation of NDs (bottom right).
    Qiong Nian
    Copyrighted
    Qiong Nian
    Image 5
  • (a) 3D printed ND-PLA samples, with cell seeding and growth; (b) fluorescent staining images to monitor the cell survival and growth.
    Qiong Nian
    Copyrighted
    Qiong Nian
    Image 6
  • MD simulation setup for CLSD process: left, carbon plasma condensation leads to formation of amorphous carbon phase; right, 3D view and slice view of shockwave induced graphite-to-diamond phase transition during CLSD.
    Qiong Nian
    Copyrighted
    Qiong Nian
    Image 2
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project established a novel confined laser shock detonation (CLSD) process to realize scalable, room-temperature nanomanufacturing of nanodiamonds (NDs) in open air towards multi-model drug delivery applications. A comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms involved in the CLSD process that could lead to fast, controlled manufacturing of NDs from graphite raw materials is gained. The major outcomes include: 1) first principles based models demonstrated that a high pressure shockwave can be generated when the laser induced plasma expansion is well confined, while the shockwave pressure and duration are closely related to the laser parameters (Image 1); 2) molecule dynamics simulation models demonstrated that the laser induced carbon plasma mainly leads to formation of amorphous carbon when they are condensed (Image 2 left), however the shockwave pressure resulted from carbon plasma expansion can well compress the meta-stable graphite and then realize the graphite-to-diamond phase transition during the CLSD process (Image 2 right); 3) molecular dynamics simulation process study demonstrated that both shockwave pressure duration and pressure magnitude have significant effects on diamond formation in the CLSD process (Image 3); 4) an ensemble learning potential demonstrated high accuracy comparing to conventional atomic potentials when it is utilized in large scale classical molecular dynamics simulations of carbon structures (Image 4); 5) A pressure-temperature window is identified in the CLSD process that ND formation will mainly happened with validation from characterizations from x-ray diffraction patterns and microscopic observations (Image 5); 6) manufactured NDs are filled into polymer matrix for 3D printing of bioimplant devices, which demonstrated ultrahigh biocompatibility promoting both cells seeding and growth (Image 6).
